text: to find alien worlds we don't have to
look very far there's a promising
candidate right in the middle of our own
solar system a strange icy world lurks
in the midst of Saturn's outer rings
Enceladus a tiny frozen moon the size of
North Dakota it's icy surface reflects
sunlight like a mirror
the ice stretches over sixty miles deep
down towards the moon's rocky core
could life exist in the darkness of this
alien world far beyond the reach of the
Sun scientists explore extreme places on
earth to help solve this mystery
Enceladus has a perfect parallel the Don
Edwards nature refuge the dried out salt
marsh the two-inch thick salt crust here
completely blocks out the Sun keeping
the ground below in eternal darkness
most of the other worlds were interested
in our solar system
it's the subsurface where we're likely
to find any life
NASA scientist Chris McKay hunts for
life that lives in the dark methanogens
tiny microbes that thrive underground
they were among the first life-forms to
appear on earth over three and a half
billion years ago perfect examples of
how life adapts and evolves on earth
anywhere where we find methanogens I'm
interested they don't like oxygen they
eat hydrogen they don't have any use of
sunlight at all they live in the deep
subsurface they are my favorite
candidates for micro astronauts on
another world
Chris searches for samples of
methanogens under the salt crust the
salt is providing a protection and also
a barrier here and the top is just the
salt the white layer then the green
layer these are organisms that use
sunlight photosynthetic then the pinkish
layer these are organisms that really
like salt then below them it's the black
stuff in there are methane producing
organisms methanogens swarmed through
this black mud 1 million of them fit on
a pinhead this will be a little tiny
model for a huge world Enceladus and by
understanding this in detail will
develop insights that we can then
generalize with
